ratings.question_text: How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-10, if you wish
comments: N/A
I feel that the use of the analityca software, by and large, is not completely relevant to the course material and learning experience.
5. I appreciated that the instructors were so open to comments to improve the class for next year.
There was some variety in quality of instruction amongst the different instructors. The pace was generally good, but towards the end I felt it was repetitive.

This was a hard course to teach, given the complexities of these linkages. I came away with a solid understanding of the concepts taught and with some ideas for future paths toward sustainability. All in all, I got what I wanted to get out of the course. I would recommend it as compared to other integrative frameworks course offerings.

Analytica was a waste of time. Too much work, too little value added. The course load overall was big on "busy work" - assignments that added little in the way of knowledge gained but took an excessive amount of time.Karen Seto was an excellent instructor with great lectures. Graedel moved very slow, but was okay. Rob Bailis was not very good.
Question 7: Karen Seto is an excellent lecturer and teacher, the classes she taught were exciting and fascinating. However, both Bailis and Graedel were dry and didn't engage the classroom well.
Expose students to multi-perspectives of sustainable issues

The course dealt with some very interested and relevant topics;brought diverse set of outside lecturers;Offered two debates with student participation;Tapped into the expertise of different professors

The themes included in the syllabus were quite interesting, and the perspectives of the instructors were interesting to learn. The best thing about this course were the debate sessions where we could truly experience the differentiated opinions from the instructors and pierce.The discussion sessions were also a highlight to this course.
My favorite classes were the debatesAppreciated that the syllabus were updated with new literature
Karen Seto is an amazing lecturer! Very engaging and her explanations were very clear.
the readings were clear, interesting, and current.

I really enjoyed my discussion section. It was an excellent chance to just talk with some of my peers in a very comfortable situation. I was fascinated by Karen Seto's lectures and thought they were extremely well done. I also really enjoyed the debates.
Thought-provoking readings, great discussions in discussion sections, and discussions in class.
Karen's lectures
Karen Seto's lectures and some of the readings

narratives.question_text: The things about this course most in need of improvement are:
comments: More effective way of conveying expert's knowledge to students
Too broadreadings often were too long and too academic (difficult to absorb)Analytica program - almost pointlessAssignments - a bit disconnected and expectations not clearly explained

This course needs for the instructors to enhance their lectures with the students reaction papers to make them a more integrated element of the learning experience.Also to try to coordination with the invited lecturers to focus on the linkages side of their issue not so much on the theoretical content of their contributions.
Pace could be a little faster -- some of the lectures were repetitive

While I appreciated the Analytica assignments, the pace of learning the software and the depth in which we learned the software, I felt a lot of that analysis could have been achieved using Excel. Given that Analytica is a paid software program, I suggest teaching analysis using software everyone has access to (like Excel) so that we may use this gained knowledge when we enter the working world.In addition, I felt as if this course was very much a survey course of sustainability and environmental issues that it might be worth offering it in the fall semester to first years rather than spring.

Clear requirements for assignments, particularly the poster. I think most students would have focused on more areas and giving particular solutions if that was pointed out as necessary for a good grade,

Figuring out the best "take away skill" for the class. I didn't find making a poster to be all that useful towards my future, nor the use of analytica. Figuring out something that is not too much work, but that you get something out of will be challenging. Excel? Public speaking? I know that the global resources relied heavily on using excel and I did not hear great things - it wasn't all that organized and turned into busy work. If you go the direction of excel, it really needs to be well thought through.

Level of effort put into Analytica and the fact that most people will not use it ever again. It was very interesting and useful software, but in the end it represents only one specialized tool out of a broad universe of information technology tools.

Rubrics and expectations for assignments need to be communicated and shared before things are due. Also, of rubrics are designed where an average or good is a 60%, that grading style also needs to be communicated before hand. This was the case with the final project grading scale, based on a conversation with the TAs.
The amount of work.
The classroom atmosphere is dead, there is no discussion.Also the Analytica assignments were not related to class-work and also nobody uses that software in the real world.

narratives.question_text: What was the availability and quality of help you received of the instructor and TA?
comments: Great - very responsive and knowledgeable
Both TAs were always on top of the assignments and the rest of the questions from the class.
Great resources
The TAs were always available to comment on projects.
The TAs were great and very responsive to all comments and questions.
Very responsive to questions about assignments, and receptive to pushback on arguments presented (content-wise).
The TAs were great. Ben Healey was responsive and helpful with Analytica assignments.
Nikki was abrasive and overzealous. Ben was fine.

narratives.question_text: Discuss if you wish how this course fits into your overall program.
comments: I thought the course would give me a better understanding of how sustainability fits into different areas of social and economic spheres. The course was too broad to give the basics and sometimes it was not clear what direction it was going.
This course helped me to complete the requirement of the capstone for the MEM. It was a good course to have a comprehensive overview of the environmental challenges of the world.
Was a required course, but thought it gave a good intro to a number of topics
It was a required class and somehow that made it less important to me. The material itself, however, was directly applicable to my interests.
I think this class raised some great issues and fits quite well for my future plans.

My focus is energy and the issue of sustainability is clearly pertinent to it. I find the course very relevant for a wide variety of fields, and am surprised that not more people took it. I think the amount of work scared some people off, and I know a few individuals that gave this reason for not taking it, which is sad because it was a very useful course.
Required.
Expected it to be a cornerstone class, but it fell short.

It was a nice overview of various environmental topics, but not much depth was added to information I already knew. Still, interesting topics were addressed which should have provoked good discussions.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: 1. It is a requirement2. Felt I need an into to sustainability and this course would give me the basics i need3. Hoped for obtain some practical skills
It was required, and it was the best option comparing with the other two courses offered as capstones.
Requirement
Integrated frameworks was required and I liked the topics being discussed in Linkages.
required.
I wanted to take a class with Karen Seto and this fulfills a requirement.
It's relevant to the issues I want to work on and it's multidisciplinary and cross-cutting (like many real world problems).
Required.
To learn about sustainability.
Required

not entirely
yes

It wasn't amazing, but it definitely exceeded expectations.

comments: Not entirely - but it definitely helped me a lot and gave me some idea where to go from here
yes

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: Group discussions; shared different opinions and ideas; interesting to hear other people's perspective on different topics
working in group for this course in particular was much relevant because you could discuss the linkages in the subject being worked at.
For a class like linkages, good to have students with different backgrounds
The poster project was great way to end the semester! I really enjoyed the assignment.
Because the class is required for MEMs it was skewed heavily to the joint-SOM crowd which I thought made discussions and in-class presentations a little biased toward economic solutions.

Advantages: getting to know classmates better, getting diversity of ideas, improvement in quality of ideas.Disadvantages: more time required per unit of output produced, coordinating schedules.Overall: good to have option to do just a little bit of groupwork, though it's also good to be able to do many projects individually.

narratives.question_text: For students taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Be prepared for a lot of work and readings. Have a good idea what exactly you want to get out of this course.
Ask as many questions as you can, this course is fantastic for class discussions and expressing points of view.
I recommend it
This class provides a good survey of environmental issues and the workload is very manageable. I'd recommend this class!
Do the readings, they are very good and will be useful to you.

They seem to working on this course, so hopefully it will be better in years to come. Its a great topic and covers some valuable topics, but wastes too much time on homework and reading responses rather than helping you process the readings in a way that gives them meaning. Karen's lectures did this really well, but that was too small a part of all the things involved in this course.
The readings are great, so read them and try to encourage class-mates to speak out.
